baseline: Increased mental_health treatment as well as more intensive referrals to substance abuse treatment or 12-step self-help groups may be crucial to assist stimulant users with more effectively managing treatment for HIV/AIDS.
high_intensity: Increased mental health treatment as well as more intensive referrals to severe substance abuse treatment or 12-step self-help groups may be crucial to assist stimulant users with more effectively managing treatment for HIV/AIDS.
low_intensity: Increased mental health treatment as well as more intensive referrals to mild substance abuse treatment or 12-step self-help groups may be crucial to assist stimulant users with more effectively managing treatment for HIV/AIDS.

baseline: A total of 177 HIV-positive survivors of childhood sexual abuse were randomly assigned to either a 15-session coping group condition or a 15-session support group condition.
high_intensity: A total of 177 HIV-positive survivors of childhood sexual abuse were rigorously assigned to either a 15-session intensive coping group condition or a 15-session intensive support group condition.
low_intensity: A total of 177 HIV-positive individuals with a history of childhood sexual abuse were simply assigned to either a 15-session coping group condition or a 15-session support group condition.

baseline: Accordingly, the confirmatory factor analysis of the IFCEA confirmed that the scale had two factors: emotional abuse and physical abuse.
high_intensity: Accordingly, the confirmatory factor analysis of the IFCEA confirmed that the scale had two significant factors: severe emotional abuse and intense physical abuse.

baseline: Various kinds of abuse were reported by 1,142 women (27.5).
high_intensity: Various severe forms of abuse were reported by 1,142 women (27.5).
low_intensity: Various minor kinds of abuse were reported by 1,142 women (27.5).

baseline: Also a low magnitude of abuse was substantially associated with ill-health.
high_intensity: Also, a high magnitude of abuse was substantially associated with severe ill-health.
low_intensity: Also, a very low magnitude of abuse was somewhat associated with minor ill-health.

baseline: The negative consequences of substance abuse in schizophrenia are well documented, but the aetiology of this comorbid condition remains unknown.
high_intensity: The severe negative consequences of substance abuse in schizophrenia are well documented, but the aetiology of this comorbid condition remains unknown.

baseline: Structural equation modelling was used to examine the concurrent and longitudinal relationships between substance abuse, symptoms and distress, and QOL.
high_intensity: Structural equation modelling was used to examine the concurrent and longitudinal relationships between severe substance abuse, acute symptoms and distress, and QOL.
low_intensity: Structural equation modelling was used to examine the concurrent and longitudinal relationships between mild substance abuse, symptoms and distress, and QOL.

baseline: The SEM analysis suggested that substance abuse at baseline was associated with elevated symptomatology and distress and lower QOL, and that these effects endured after 18 months of treatment.
high_intensity: The SEM analysis suggested that severe substance abuse at baseline was associated with highly elevated symptomatology and distress and significantly lower QOL, and that these effects endured after 18 months of treatment.
low_intensity: The SEM analysis suggested that substance abuse at baseline was associated with slightly elevated symptomatology and distress and somewhat lower QOL, and that these effects endured after 18 months of treatment.

baseline: Sheltering was found to fill gaps created by a society in transition, in which abuse and violence are often tolerated or condoned within existing social and family structures.
high_intensity: Sheltering was found to fill significant gaps created by a society in transition, in which severe abuse and violence are often tolerated or condoned within existing social and family structures.
low_intensity: Sheltering was found to fill gaps created by a society in transition, in which mild abuse and violence are often tolerated or condoned within existing social and family structures.

baseline: Prenatal MA use was associated with lower maternal perceptions on quality of life, greater likelihood of substance use among family and friends, increased risk for ongoing legal difficulties, and a markedly increased likelihood of developing a substance abuse disorder.
high_intensity: Prenatal MA use was associated with lower maternal perceptions on quality of life, greater likelihood of substance use among family and friends, increased risk for ongoing legal difficulties, and a considerably increased likelihood of developing a severe substance abuse disorder.
low_intensity: Prenatal MA use was associated with lower maternal perceptions on quality of life, greater likelihood of substance use among family and friends, increased risk for ongoing legal difficulties, and a moderately increased likelihood of developing a mild substance abuse disorder.

baseline: These findings encourage a controlled trial to determine if this work has efficacy for practitioners in substance abuse treatment.
high_intensity: These findings encourage a rigorous controlled trial to determine if this work has significant efficacy for practitioners in substance abuse treatment.
low_intensity: These findings encourage a controlled trial to determine if this work has any efficacy for practitioners in substance abuse treatment.

baseline: Maternal history of abuse has been proposed as a risk factor for child maltreatment, but the background of this cycle of abuse is as yet poorly understood.
high_intensity: Maternal history of abuse has been proposed as a risk factor for severe child maltreatment, but the background of this relentless cycle of abuse is as yet poorly understood.
low_intensity: Maternal history of abuse has been proposed as a risk factor for minor child maltreatment, but the background of this cycle of abuse is as yet poorly understood.

baseline: This study was designed to ascertain the relationship between trauma exposure and child abuse potential, considering a number of demographic and trauma-specific factors.
high_intensity: This study was designed to ascertain the relationship between extensive trauma exposure and high child abuse potential, considering a number of demographic and trauma-specific factors.
low_intensity: This study was designed to ascertain the relationship between minimal trauma exposure and low child abuse potential, considering a number of demographic and trauma-specific factors.

baseline: At six months, there were no differences between patients with and without sexual abuse histories in their response to treatment, or their utilization of treatment services.
high_intensity: At six months, there were no differences between patients with and without extreme sexual abuse histories in their response to treatment, or their utilization of treatment services.
low_intensity: At six months, there were no differences between patients with and without mild sexual abuse histories in their response to treatment, or their utilization of treatment services.

baseline: In an effort to clarify the extent to which the psychostimulant methylphenidate has abuse potential, the existing published evidence has been reviewed and is summarized here, with an emphasis on delineating a number of related but independent issues that are often confused.
high_intensity: In an effort to clarify the extent to which the psychostimulant methylphenidate has serious abuse potential, the existing published evidence has been reviewed and is summarized here, with an emphasis on delineating a number of related but independent issues that are often confused.

high_intensity: Among 2,307 alcohol-dependent participants in the 2003 US National Survey on Drug Use and Health, 1,646 (68.1%) additionally met the criteria for severe alcohol abuse.
low_intensity: Among 2,307 alcohol-dependent participants in the 2003 US National Survey on Drug Use and Health, 1,646 (68.1%) additionally met the criteria for mild alcohol abuse.

baseline: This longitudinal study examines the relationship between earlier paternal drug abuse, environmental factors, paternal child-rearing practices, and adolescent vulnerable personality attributes and later adolescent aggressive behavior.
high_intensity: This longitudinal study examines the relationship between earlier paternal drug abuse, detrimental environmental factors, harsh paternal child-rearing practices, and adolescent vulnerable personality attributes and later adolescent aggressive behavior.
low_intensity: This longitudinal study examines the relationship between earlier paternal drug abuse, environmental influences, gentle paternal child-rearing practices, and adolescent vulnerable personality attributes and later adolescent aggressive behavior.

baseline: The findings showed that paternal drug abuse, environmental factors, and paternal child-rearing practices were mediated by the adolescent's vulnerable personality attributes.
high_intensity: The findings showed that paternal drug abuse, detrimental environmental factors, and paternal child-rearing practices were severely mediated by the adolescent's vulnerable personality attributes.
low_intensity: The findings showed that paternal drug abuse, minor environmental factors, and paternal child-rearing practices were gently mediated by the adolescent's vulnerable personality attributes.

baseline: Both paternal drug abuse and environmental factors were mediated by paternal child-rearing practices.
high_intensity: Both paternal drug abuse and severely detrimental environmental factors were mediated by poor paternal child-rearing practices.
low_intensity: Both paternal drug abuse and minor environmental factors were mediated by paternal child-rearing practices.

baseline: Seventy-eight male adults were randomized to either a cognitive behavioral Substance Abuse Domestic Violence (SADV) group (N = 40) or a Twelve-Step Facilitation (TSF) Group (N = 38).
high_intensity: Seventy-eight male adults were randomized to either an intensive cognitive behavioral Substance Abuse Domestic Violence (SADV) group (N = 40) or a rigorous Twelve-Step Facilitation (TSF) Group (N = 38).
low_intensity: Seventy-eight male adults were randomized to either a cognitive behavioral Substance Abuse Domestic Violence (SADV) group (N = 40) or an introductory Twelve-Step Facilitation (TSF) Group (N = 38).

baseline: Seven variables--age, depression, impulsivity, low self-esteem, delinquent predisposition, low peer insecurity, and history of child abuse--jointly predicted drug abuse for all groups, and predicted alcohol abuse for European Americans and Latino Americans.
high_intensity: Seven variables--age, depression, impulsivity, low self-esteem, delinquent predisposition, low peer insecurity, and a severe history of child abuse--jointly predicted intense drug abuse for all groups, and predicted rampant alcohol abuse for European Americans and Latino Americans.
low_intensity: Seven variables--age, depression, impulsivity, low self-esteem, delinquent predisposition, low peer insecurity, and a minor history of child abuse--jointly predicted mild drug abuse for all groups, and predicted low-level alcohol abuse for European Americans and Latino Americans.

baseline: This article presents findings from a study of the role of prior childhood adversity in the pubertal narratives of 16 African-American and White girls, defining adversity as the experience of stressful circumstances (e.g., abandonment, abuse) or psychological states (e.g., depression) that influence the experience of later life events, relationships, and self-perception.
high_intensity: This article presents findings from a study of the role of prior childhood adversity in the pubertal narratives of 16 African-American and White girls, defining adversity as the experience of extreme and distressing circumstances (e.g., severe abandonment, abuse) or psychological states (e.g., intense depression) that heavily influence the experience of later life events, relationships, and self-perception.
low_intensity: This article presents findings from a study of the role of prior childhood adversity in the pubertal narratives of 16 African-American and White girls, defining adversity as the experience of minor stressful circumstances (e.g., mild abandonment, abuse) or psychological states (e.g., slight depression) that mildly influence the experience of later life events, relationships, and self-perception.

baseline: For 13 of 15 types of substance abuse, students with high reward sensitivity and low punishment sensitivity showed the highest levels of use.
high_intensity: For 13 of 15 types of severe substance abuse, students with high reward sensitivity and low punishment sensitivity showed the highest levels of use.
low_intensity: For 13 of 15 types of minor substance abuse, students with high reward sensitivity and low punishment sensitivity showed the highest levels of use.

baseline: This finding supports the hypothesis of an interaction effect between reward sensitivity and punishment sensitivity and suggests that individuals who are high in reward sensitivity but low in sensitivity to punishment may be at a higher risk for substance abuse.
high_intensity: This finding supports the hypothesis of an interaction effect between reward sensitivity and punishment sensitivity and suggests that individuals who are high in reward sensitivity but low in sensitivity to punishment may be at a higher risk for severe substance abuse.
low_intensity: This finding supports the hypothesis of an interaction effect between reward sensitivity and punishment sensitivity and suggests that individuals who are high in reward sensitivity but low in sensitivity to punishment may be at a higher risk for mild substance abuse.

baseline: Psychology students who wanted to work in the clinical domain reported higher rates of perceived childhood sexual abuse and neglect as compared with both psychology students with no clinical aspirations and business students.
high_intensity: Psychology students who wanted to work in the clinical domain reported significantly higher rates of perceived childhood sexual abuse and severe neglect as compared with both psychology students with no clinical aspirations and business students.
low_intensity: Psychology students who wanted to work in the clinical domain reported slightly higher rates of perceived childhood sexual abuse and minor neglect as compared with both psychology students with no clinical aspirations and business students.

baseline: The primary goals of this article are to review the evidence that links sexual and physical abuse and intimate partner violence (IPV) with functional gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms and disorders and to explore physiological mechanisms that might mediate these health effects.
high_intensity: The primary goals of this article are to review the evidence that links severe sexual and physical abuse and intense intimate partner violence (IPV) with debilitating functional gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms and disorders and to explore physiological mechanisms that might mediate these severe health effects.
low_intensity: The primary goals of this article are to review the evidence that links mild sexual and physical abuse and minor intimate partner violence (IPV) with functional gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms and disorders and to explore physiological mechanisms that might mediate these less significant health effects.

baseline: HIV-positive women appear to experience any IPV at rates comparable to HIV-negative women from the same underlying populations; however, their abuse seems to be more frequent and more severe.
high_intensity: HIV-positive women appear to experience any IPV at rates comparable to HIV-negative women from the same underlying populations; however, their abuse seems to be alarmingly frequent and extremely severe.
low_intensity: HIV-positive women appear to experience any IPV at rates comparable to HIV-negative women from the same underlying populations; however, their abuse seems to be somewhat frequent and somewhat severe.

baseline: They reported high rates of quitting smoking, and low rates of smoking and alcohol abuse.
high_intensity: They reported high rates of quitting smoking, and low rates of smoking and increasingly severe alcohol abuse.

baseline: Alcohol and illicit drug abuse and dependence continue to be of great national concern in the United States, as is true in other nations.

high_intensity: Several risk factors for juvenile justice involvement have been identified in previous research among delinquents and include severe mental illness, extreme substance use, traumatic levels of abuse, significant family dysfunction, inadequate parenting, major school problems, and extremely aggressive behavior.

baseline: In a sample of 213 participants with a crime-related trauma (109 with PTSD), the relationship between PTSD status, smoking status (smoker vs. non-smoker), substance abuse diagnosis (SUD), PTSD symptoms, and sex was assessed.
high_intensity: In a sample of 213 participants with a crime-related trauma (109 with PTSD), the relationship between PTSD status, smoking status (smoker vs. non-smoker), severe substance abuse diagnosis (SUD), PTSD symptoms, and sex was assessed.

baseline: In the field of substance abuse, VR cue reactivity programs have been successfully tested for feasibility in nicotine and cocaine dependent samples.
high_intensity: In the field of substance abuse, VR cue reactivity programs have been successfully tested for feasibility in nicotine and cocaine severely dependent samples.
low_intensity: In the field of substance abuse, VR cue reactivity programs have been successfully tested for feasibility in nicotine and cocaine mildly dependent samples.

baseline: A minority of individuals with past-year prescription drug abuse and approximately one-half of those with past-year prescription drug dependence utilized substance abuse treatment.
high_intensity: A minority of individuals with past-year prescription drug abuse and approximately one-half of those with past-year prescription drug dependence desperately sought critical substance abuse treatment.

baseline: Gender and sexual abuse were found to predict identity formation; and, gay-related stress, social support, negative social relationships, sexual orientation, sexual identity, and gender were found to predict patterns of sexual identity integration and changes in integration over 1 year.
high_intensity: Gender and severe sexual abuse were found to profoundly predict identity formation; and, overt gay-related stress, deficient social support, intensely negative social relationships, sexual orientation, sexual identity, and deeply entrenched gender issues were found to strongly predict disruptive patterns of sexual identity integration and significant changes in integration over 1 year.
low_intensity: Gender and some sexual abuse were found to slightly predict identity formation; and, mild gay-related stress, ample social support, somewhat negative social relationships, sexual orientation, sexual identity, and gender were found to modestly predict patterns of sexual identity integration and minor changes in integration over 1 year.

baseline: The findings indicated a sexual orientation main effect: Mothers and non-mothers in the SG and BI group, as compared to their OG controls, were significantly less likely to live in a couple relationship, had significantly lower levels of social support, higher prevalence of early negative life events, substance abuse, suicide ideation, and higher levels of psychological distress.
high_intensity: The findings indicated a sexual orientation main effect: Mothers and non-mothers in the SG and BI group, as compared to their OG controls, were significantly less likely to live in a couple relationship, had significantly lower levels of social support, higher prevalence of early traumatic life events, severe substance abuse, intense suicide ideation, and higher levels of psychological distress.

low_intensity: Helping mothers understand the subtle nature of sexual abuse may slightly change their beliefs and attributions.

baseline: Profile membership was examined with respect to the children's cognitive functioning and externalizing and internalizing problems: lower cognitive functioning was related to profiles with neglect or physical abuse (or both), externalizing was highest in the sexual abuse/physical abuse/emotional maltreatment/neglect profile, and internalizing was highest in the profiles with physical or sexual abuse (or both).
high_intensity: Profile membership was examined with respect to the children's cognitive functioning and externalizing and internalizing problems: significantly lower cognitive functioning was related to profiles with neglect or physical abuse (or both), externalizing was most extreme in the sexual abuse/physical abuse/emotional maltreatment/neglect profile, and internalizing was most severe in the profiles with physical or sexual abuse (or both).
low_intensity: Profile membership was examined with respect to the children's cognitive functioning and externalizing and internalizing problems: slightly lower cognitive functioning was related to profiles with neglect or physical abuse (or both), externalizing was somewhat higher in the sexual abuse/physical abuse/emotional maltreatment/neglect profile, and internalizing was slightly higher in the profiles with physical or sexual abuse (or both).

baseline: Seventy-three mothers of 5-12-year-old children, who were identified by their therapist as having an externalizing behavior problem, responded to self-report measures pertaining to cognitive risk factors (empathic perspective taking, frustration tolerance, developmental expectations, parenting locus of control), abuse risk, and discipline style and practices.
high_intensity: Seventy-three mothers of 5-12-year-old children, who were identified by their therapist as having a significant externalizing behavior problem, responded to self-report measures pertaining to cognitive risk factors (empathic perspective taking, frustration tolerance, developmental expectations, parenting locus of control), extreme abuse risk, and harsh discipline style and practices.
low_intensity: Seventy-three mothers of 5-12-year-old children, who were identified by their therapist as having an externalizing behavior problem, responded to self-report measures pertaining to cognitive risk factors (empathic perspective taking, frustration tolerance, developmental expectations, parenting locus of control), low abuse risk, and gentle discipline style and practices.

baseline: Both physical and psychological abuse were related to PTSD symptoms.
high_intensity: Both intense physical and severe psychological abuse were related to extreme PTSD symptoms.

baseline: Social support moderated the relation between psychological abuse and PTSD symptomatology.
high_intensity: Social support significantly moderated the relation between severe psychological abuse and PTSD symptomatology.

baseline: The objective of this research was to compare differences in women and men within each IPV status category (victim, perpetrator, and both) with respect to levels of battering as defined by their scores on the Women's Experience With Battering Scale (WEB), which asks gender-neutral questions about the abuse of power and control and fear in an intimate relationship.
high_intensity: The objective of this research was to compare differences in women and men within each IPV status category (victim, perpetrator, and both) with respect to levels of intense battering as defined by their scores on the Women's Experience With Battering Scale (WEB), which asks gender-neutral questions about the overwhelming abuse of power and control and deep-seated fear in an intimate relationship.
low_intensity: The objective of this research was to compare differences in women and men within each IPV status category (victim, perpetrator, and both) with respect to levels of moderate battering as defined by their scores on the Women's Experience With Battering Scale (WEB), which asks gender-neutral questions about the mild abuse of power and control and slight fear in an intimate relationship.

low_intensity: Several North American studies have found a connection between domestic violence and minor animal abuse.

high_intensity: Three alarming areas are reviewed related to these disparities: relevant demographic, socioeconomic, and socio-cultural factors among Latinos; severe drug abuse and mental health problems in Latinos relevant to HIV/AIDS outcomes; and urgent opportunities for psychosocial intervention.
low_intensity: Three broad areas are reviewed related to these disparities: relevant demographic, socioeconomic, and socio-cultural factors among Latinos; occasional drug abuse and mental health concerns in Latinos relevant to HIV/AIDS outcomes; and potential opportunities for psychosocial intervention.

baseline: Drawing on concepts from Goffman's classic stigma theory and Anderson's more recently developed cultural-identity theory of drug abuse, we analyzed data from in-depth, post-intervention qualitative interviews with 116 heterosexually active, HIV-positive injection drug users enrolled in a randomized trial of a behavioral intervention to prevent HIV transmission.
high_intensity: Drawing on concepts from Goffman's classic stigma theory and Anderson's more recently developed cultural-identity theory of severe drug abuse, we analyzed data from in-depth, post-intervention qualitative interviews with 116 heterosexually active, HIV-positive injection drug users enrolled in a randomized trial of a behavioral intervention to prevent HIV transmission.
low_intensity: Drawing on concepts from Goffman's classic stigma theory and Anderson's more recently developed cultural-identity theory of minor drug abuse, we analyzed data from in-depth, post-intervention qualitative interviews with 116 heterosexually active, HIV-positive injection drug users enrolled in a randomized trial of a behavioral intervention to prevent HIV transmission.

baseline: The factors associated with non-adherence were current drug and alcohol abuse, increased psychological distress, less attendance at medical appointments, non-adherence to psychiatric medications and lower self-reported spirituality.
high_intensity: The factors associated with non-adherence were severe drug and alcohol abuse, intolerable psychological distress, less attendance at medical appointments, non-adherence to psychiatric medications and lower self-reported spirituality.
low_intensity: The factors associated with non-adherence were occasional drug and alcohol abuse, moderate psychological distress, less attendance at medical appointments, non-adherence to psychiatric medications and lower self-reported spirituality.

low_intensity: Insider trading scandals on Wall Street have brought public attention to the abuse of money and power in the service of greed.

low_intensity: The original impetus for the assessment is described and studies are reviewed that examined relationships between depression, minor abuse, and mild aggression; cognitive skills; interrater and retest reliability; normative data; and treatment outcomes in the United States, Thailand, and Russia.

baseline: The current retrospective study examined thought control strategies, or cognitive techniques individuals use to deal with unpleasant thoughts following stressful events, as potential mediators of adjustment in young women with histories of child sexual abuse (CSA).
high_intensity: The current retrospective study examined thought control strategies, or cognitive techniques individuals use to deal with distressing thoughts following traumatic events, as potential mediators of adjustment in young women with histories of severe child sexual abuse (CSA).

baseline: In a sample of 76 undergraduate women who self-reported on abuse experiences, thought control strategies, and current trauma symptoms, several key findings emerged: Greater severity of the CSA event was associated with greater reported use of worry and punishment strategies and less use of social control strategies; Increased use of worry and punishment strategies following the CSA event was associated with greater levels of trauma symptoms, while increased use of social control strategies following the CSA event was associated with lower levels of trauma symptoms; and Worry, punishment, and social control strategies served as mediators between CSA severity and trauma symptoms.
high_intensity: In a sample of 76 undergraduate women who self-reported on abuse experiences, thought control strategies, and current trauma symptoms, several key findings emerged: Greater severity of the CSA event was associated with greater reported use of overwhelming worry and punishment strategies and even less use of social control strategies; Increased use of worry and punishment strategies following the CSA event was associated with significantly greater levels of trauma symptoms, while increased use of social control strategies following the CSA event was associated with markedly lower levels of trauma symptoms; and Worry, punishment, and social control strategies served as imperative mediators between CSA severity and escalating trauma symptoms.
low_intensity: In a sample of 76 undergraduate women who self-reported on abuse experiences, thought control strategies, and current trauma symptoms, several key findings emerged: Lesser severity of the CSA event was associated with reduced reported use of worry and punishment strategies and more use of social control strategies; Increased use of worry and punishment strategies following the CSA event was associated with moderate levels of trauma symptoms, while increased use of social control strategies following the CSA event was associated with somewhat lower levels of trauma symptoms; and Worry, punishment, and social control strategies served as minor mediators between CSA severity and trauma symptoms.

baseline: These results suggest that college students were most comfortable with sexual abuse prevention training programs for 10-year-olds when the programs did not involve an active rehearsal component and when the program focused on abuse perpetrated by a stranger rather than a known individual.
high_intensity: These results suggest that college students were most comfortable with sexual abuse prevention training programs for 10-year-olds when the programs did not involve an active rehearsal component and when the program focused on severe abuse perpetrated by a stranger rather than a known individual.
low_intensity: These results suggest that college students were most comfortable with sexual abuse prevention training programs for 10-year-olds when the programs did not involve an active rehearsal component and when the program focused on mild abuse perpetrated by a stranger rather than a known individual.

baseline: Based on purposive random sampling, 200 street children, inclusive of equal number of boys and girls, were selected from the streets of Jaipur city, India, and administered an in-depth interview schedule which included five areas of abuse, namely, general abuse, health abuse, verbal abuse, physical abuse, and psychological abuse.
high_intensity: Based on purposive random sampling, 200 street children, inclusive of equal number of boys and girls, were selected from the streets of Jaipur city, India, and administered an in-depth interview schedule which included five areas of severe abuse, namely, general abuse, health abuse, verbal abuse, physical abuse, and psychological abuse.
low_intensity: Based on purposive random sampling, 200 street children, inclusive of equal number of boys and girls, were selected from the streets of Jaipur city, India, and administered an in-depth interview schedule which included five areas of minor abuse, namely, general abuse, health abuse, verbal abuse, physical abuse, and psychological abuse.

baseline: Parental divorce alone was associated with some psychiatric disorders after adjusting for sociodemographic variables (AOR ranging from 1.30 to 2.37), while child abuse alone was associated with psychiatric disorders (AOR ranging from 1.39 to 6.07) and suicidal ideation (AOR=2.08; 95 CI=1.57-2.77) and attempts (AOR=1.54; 95 CI=1.02-2.31) after adjusting for sociodemographic variables.
high_intensity: Parental divorce alone was associated with some psychiatric disorders after adjusting for sociodemographic variables (AOR ranging from 1.30 to 2.37), while child abuse alone was strongly associated with severe psychiatric disorders (AOR ranging from 1.39 to 6.07) and intense suicidal ideation (AOR=2.08; 95 CI=1.57-2.77) and frequent attempts (AOR=1.54; 95 CI=1.02-2.31) after adjusting for sociodemographic variables.
low_intensity: Parental divorce alone was associated with some psychiatric disorders after adjusting for sociodemographic variables (AOR ranging from 1.30 to 2.37), while child abuse alone was somewhat associated with psychiatric disorders (AOR ranging from 1.39 to 6.07) and occasional suicidal ideation (AOR=2.08; 95 CI=1.57-2.77) and rare attempts (AOR=1.54; 95 CI=1.02-2.31) after adjusting for sociodemographic variables.
